article_title: Conference promotes disruption of medical technology
article_text: PhysioCare starts with a downloaded app that leads to selection of a physical therapist, a 45-minute exam and the creation of what she calls a “personal care plan” prescribed by a doctor of physical therapy. Jarmusz, a doctor of physical therapy student at Northeastern University, said her plan would not replace the annual exam of a physician, but be in addition to it. “Physical therapists are better suited to assess the musculoskeletal system,” Jarmusz said.

article_metadata.description:
NEW CASTLE – A day-long conference Friday sought to use technology to turn health care on its head.
For example, people normally see a physical therapist to treat an injury or recover from surgery. But what if physical therapy, using an app-based tool, was used to prevent the injury? That was one example of some ideas presented at “Disruptivate! Healthcare 2015” (www.disruptivatehealthcare.com), which presented new ideas for old approaches to medicine and patient care.
The
article_metadata.author: Paul Briand news@seacoastonline.com

article_summary:
“Physical therapists are better suited to assess the musculoskeletal system,” Jarmusz said.
Jarmusz, a doctor of physical therapy student at Northeastern University, said her plan would not replace the annual exam of a physician, but be in addition to it.
PhysioCare starts with a downloaded app that leads to selection of a physical therapist, a 45-minute exam and the creation of what she calls a “personal care plan” prescribed by a doctor of physical therapy.
